product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Lightweight, Fast, Portable
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 3, 2023
text: I really love this hard-drive!Pros:The storage capacity of this hard drive is truly impressive. I was able to back up all my important files, including photos, videos, music, and documents, with plenty of space to spare.The transfer speed is very fast thanks to the USB 3.0 connection. I was able to transfer large files, such as high-resolution videos and RAW photo files, quickly and easily.The hard drive is very lightweight and compact, making it easy to carry around with me. I appreciate that it doesn't take up much space on my desk or in my bag.The design of the hard drive is sleek and modern, with a brushed metal finish that looks great. It matches well with my Mac mini and other devices.Setting up the hard drive was extremely easy. I simply plugged it into my MacBook Pro and was able to start transferring files immediately. I didn't have to install any software or drivers.The price of this hard drive is very reasonable, especially considering the large storage capacity and fast transfer speeds.Cons:While the hard drive isn't particularly loud, it can be a bit noisy when it's in use. I noticed a slight humming sound when transferring large files.The hard drive doesn't come with a protective case or cover, which could be a concern if you plan to travel with it frequently. I would recommend purchasing a separate case or sleeve to protect it from scratches and damage.This thing provides plenty of storage space and fast transfer speeds, making it an excellent choice for anyone who needs to back up large amounts of data. The hard drive is extremely lightweight, compact, and easy to use, with a sleek design that looks great. While the noise level and lack of a protective case are minor concerns, they do not detract from the overall quality and value of the product. I would highly recommend the Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD to anyone in need of a reliable and high-capacity external hard drive.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: It will work for Mac running Monterey
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2022
text: Like many others I could not get the computer to recognize the drive and the as I procrastinated one day it just showed up - there are answers for that so I am going to skip to how to make it work for your Mac running Monterey. The Seagate drive is made for Windows but if you reformat it by erasing it it WILL work. So, go to Disc Utility and select the Seagate drive and erase it by first naming it, the format it as Mac Journaled, then, and this is the important part, select Guid Partition Map.If for any reason the erase fails it's because your system preferences are open, just restart the computer after closing all the windows that are open. Then the erase will work, that is how it gets formatted for a Mac.Now go to Time Machine and select the Seagate that  you have named (I named mine the name of the incredible tech support person at Seagate) and tell it that you want to replace whatever you had before with this new one.So, I had a Seagate drive that I bought in 2019 that just stopped working one day. My tech support guy told me to always eject the drive by dragging the icon down to the trash when it's not in use - then it will last a long time. Power surges kill them, mine died when I turned off the computer in the middle of something in a panic over what I thought was a breach. It was nothing, but the little drive never worked again and so only 3 years later I had to buy another, but I will be more careful.Anyway, I hope this advice works for you but if not the tech support people at Seagate are great.I took off a star because there is no info on the website and none came with it either.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Must format to ExFAT if using a Macbook
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 17, 2023
text: I purchased this portable hard drive to use on a Macbook Air. To my surprise it was not formatted for a Mac computer, although it is advertised as such. This portable hard drive is formatted for Windows. I called seagate to help me reformat the hard drive to be able to use it on my Mac. The instructions where to go to utility disk, find this hard drive, select it, erase the hard drive, and choose the ExFAT in the format option. The ExFAT format allows you to use the hard drive on a Mac and Windows. This worked for me, may not necessarily work for you.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Excellence
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2023
text: Seagate USA has been making the best drives (RLL,MFM,IDE,SCSI) since before most buyers were born.Some people seem to not have matched USB3.0 HD to USB3.0 port on their PC.  It is not uncommon for a PC to expose both USB2.0 and 3.0 without labels: which can cause unexpected slow transfers.The drive isn't to be roughtly handled and while operating should not be moved or touched (although I have a little without consequence).The drive takes longer to write than read:  this is in the advertised specifications to see plainly - it does exactly as it said it would do - precisely.Read the pre-purchase specs:  Drives do not come formatted "especially for you".  They absolutely must be preformatted with one filesystem only:  due to microsoft apple ubuntu (and others) in a kinda war - it's likely the format may need reformatting before use.  Seagate has no magic to know "which you need" nor could they:  this "war" includes hiding formatting specifications.

text: I use this product for work to store files on. I've had it for a year now and I feel I can give a pretty good reivew. The storage space is wonderful. However, due to some sort of software or technical issues, I have not found the answer to as of yet, all I know is that it is not my computer's issue, its the hard drive's issue. Nothing is wrong on the computer end. But for some reason it likes to "time out" for lack of a better term. Randomly, and that's what's annoying about it, I could be using it for work and it just shuts off on me. Leaving me to unplug and replug. Several times a day. Nothing happens to it, it does it all on its own. Due to me unplugging and plugging back in so many times a day, obvioulsy the cord was going to wear. Well, this morning it took a bow and decided to not work anymore. So now I have a hardrive full of work files, that doesn't work anymroe because the cord now does not work. So, for over $50, I dont think this is a good product for the money. For over $50 I expect the device to work properly for one, and two, the cord should hold up  more than a phone charger holds up. Maybe its the plug design on the device. I dont know. But something needs to change, because this obviously isnt working. I'm disappointed in this product.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Slow, Reliable, & Shuckable.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2023
text: I'm giving this 5 stars because it's a perfect back-up drive to support 3-2-1 backup strategy. Some general notes and considerations below:1. These are SMR drives, as are all 2.5" hdd drives over 500gb. When these drives are new and empty, the write speeds are pretty comparable to other hard drives but as the fill up they do slow down a bit. If you are using these for backup and archival, you need reliable storage, not blazing fast speeds and these are great.2. These drives are Shuckable, meaning you can break open the case and take the hard drive out and use it in your own enclosure or laptop. This is important because if the drives USB connector wears out of breaks, you have options to recover your data and continue using the drive. Most Toshiba and Western Digital external hard drives have proprietary connections and can't be used in another enclosure, so if your USB port on those drives fails your entire drive is trash.3. High Capacity at low cost. You don't need the highest quality drive to protect your data, you need multiple decent quality drives so you can have multiple copies in case a drive fails on you. The price per TB of these drives is a great value.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Rugged, easy and reliable
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 27, 2021
text: ProsWithstands the (involuntary) 2 ft fall testAdequate physical size to carry around (or flee from a disaster area)Manufacturer's technical support and test softwareGood warrantyConsBundled backup and restore program runs only full backups, not incremental or differential onesComputer hiccups, hardware failures, disasters or viruses? When they hit, it may be too late to rescue your precious files and digital photos. That's why I believe in backups, and the reason why acquired the Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive Portable HDD – USB 3.0 when I had a fair amount of reward points accumulated somewhere.This is the second brand name external HDD that I've used of more than 500GB and the 4th one that I have used in recent memory (the other 3 were a generic one I assembled with a COMPUSA external HDD enclosure and a Western Digital 20GB HDD, the other was a SyQuest removable external drive (remember those?) and another brand-name 1TB). It's so small (smaller then my other 1TB drive) that it can fit in the corner of my emergency evacuation bag.The Seagate brand has been around since the birth of the personal computer era and, as both a user and a computer service technician, I had a history of generally good and reliable experiences with it. So, I was looking forward to a similar experience and, generally,  I've been pleased.Oh, I forgot: just when I recently opened the box it came in, it slipped from my hand to the floor, 2 to 3 ft. “Game Over!”- I though. So,... with some trepidation, I connected it to my Windows 10 Home laptop computer and, Voila! It worked! Just in case, I downloaded and installed in my computer the Seagate's SeaTools for Windows and tested it overnight: passed. I copied the contents of my other 1TB external HDD to it. Rugged, isn't it. No issues, so far.Once I registered it by running the “Start Here Win” routine from the drive, I got to download and install the “Seagate DiscWizard”, a nifty program offered as bundled to clone, backup and restore drives and data files. I ran an Entire Computer backup (the equivalent of a full backup) of my laptop and it did it in 11 minutes and 39 seconds: not bad. Then, I tested restoring by deleting an image file from my regular user account, rebooted the computer, ran DiscWizard, had to enter my administrator's password, selected Recovery (the software's term for Restore) and browse down to the file I knew was missing and restored it to my user account. That was easy, but,... DiscWizard won't allow for incremental or differential backups. On the other hand, every time you run an entire computer backup, the program overwrites the previous backup. If you are backing up or recovering a laptop computer, be sure that 1) its battery is fully charged and 2) that its connected to its own AC adapter and 3) “backup fully, backup often”.A worst case scenario of the Seagate external drive becoming non-responsive or missing part or all your backup, may call for Rescue DATA RECOVERY SERVICES, included with the purchase of the drive. This is a plus (although, I prefer not to have to use it).I look forward to use it as my main backup device, while turning my other 1TB drive to a day to day external storage unit. Verdict: 4 stars!All photos (c) 2021 by reviewer.

title: Ps4 troubleshooting
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2023
text: For those who are having trouble on the ps4, I just bought the 2TB external hard drive and had to research how to get it to recognize my device. Here are the steps:1. Plug into computer and format the hard drive to exFAT2. Turn off ps4 and do not plug in the hard drive just yet.3. Turn on ps4 and wait for it to get to your choose profile screen.4. Plug the hard drive usb into the usb input located at the front and most-left side of the ps4.5. It should be recognized and even tell you so. Then just follow instructions from the ps4 to format it once more.

Spent many hours trying different ways but nothing worked until I found out on the web I would need to reformat the drive into a Mac friendly format. title: Seagate Support is Excellent
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 23, 2022
text: This EHD worked great right out of the box and was perfect for me needs.  Until, unfortunately, the plug in jack got loose and I could no longer get a good connection to my laptop.  It was still under warranty and had rescue service with it as well.  I called Seagate support and they promptly sent me a paid label to return the drive.  They emailed me when it was recieved and at each step in the process.  Within 2 weeks, I had a new hard drive with all of my data recovered back to it.  So good to know that the warranty did in fact work out when I needed it.  I will be more careful plugging and unplugging in the future.

title: No quick start guide
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 8, 2022
text: The write up for this Seagate XHD indicated it was compatible with Microsoft and Apple products and that it was plug and play. It came with no quick start guide. I plugged it in, it came on, and I tested dragging and dropping a document. It didn't work. I went to Seagate and registered the XHD and went on their chat. There I found that it was set up for Microsoft; to use it on Mac, I had to download software - how 1980's. This is my third Seagate XHD and that's never happened to me before. Why did I have to go on a hunt for it when they could have just included a link to the software with the hard drive? I knocked off one star for poor customer information.

title: Xbox Series S
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 12, 2022
text: I can confirm that this external hard drive works with the xbox series s. The only problem is that you cannot play optimised games for the series x/s on the drive, but that will always be the case no matter what external hard drive or ssd you get for your series x/s. You can store optimised games on the drive, but you cannot play them unless you move them into the internal storage. You can still play any other games on the hard drive as long as it is not optimised for the console. Only problem I actually have with this drive is that it's actually about 1.8tb, but I assume every other 2tb hard drive has the same problem.Edit: This goes unsaid, but I assume this hard drive also works with the xbox series x.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Good, Solid External HDD
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on June 8, 2022
text: I bought this External HDD to use with my new PS5, and it works wonderfully.  I keep all of my PS4 games stored on this external drive to save room on the console's internal SSD for the PS5 games (which can only be run from the internal SSD) and I haven't noticed any significant load-time slowdowns as opposed to the SSD.I already have a 1 terabyte model I use to store music and video files, and I was originally going to purchase a 5 terabyte model for about $110 to use with my new PS5, but I decided that 2 terabytes was fine for my current needs.  The 5 terabyte model is also an excellent deal (just five years ago i would have thought 5 terabytes of storage for only 110 bucks was completely insane!) and I may decide to get an additional 5 terabyte model in a few months, and repurpose my 2 terabyte drive for something else.  In a month or two I plan on buying a 2 terabyte internal SSD to install as a second drive in my PS5, and having both a 2 terabyte Internal SSD AND a 5 terabyte External HDD should future-proof my PS5 console for quite a while as far as storage space goes.This 2 Terabyte External HDD works wonderfully; I have loaded it up with all of my current PS4 games and still have a full terabyte left, and I have not noticed any loading slowdown on any of my PS4 games installed on it, including DooM (2016), Spider-Man, and Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Great portable hard drive at a decent price!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2022
text: I only buy Seagate or Western Digital products for my storage needs because they have never failed me. It's setup to run on Windows from the get go but I use Linux so I reformatted it to be more compatible. I have to do that with every portable hard drive I get but the process doesn't take long. It does have extra software on it but even if you use Windows you can remove it to free up more space on the drive. I'm not sure if you would have to reformat it for a Mac or not. Maybe check the description and see if its Mac compatible. I would think it is but I may be wrong. 2TB of space is a lot more than most people actually need but some of us have years worth of stuff we like to save. So if you have a lot of music, movies, documents, pictures etc, this would be ideal for you. Just remember it is a standard hard drive so if you drop it, especially on a hard surface, poof goes all your data. Not every time, that is if you're lucky, but a lot of the time that will happen or there will be damage to the hard drive that can cause read/write issues. Solid state drives are more reliable but also more expensive. Anyway for a 2TB portable drive at around $40 something bucks isn't a bad deal. As long as you're careful with it and do regular backups. Don't want to lose your data in a computer crash!

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Satisfied so far
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2022
text: Price was very fair, packaging generic (not retail) but good, and trouble-free so far. I used it for a 450GB Time Machine backup on a 2012 MacBook Pro, and Time Machine estimated it would take15 hours. It didn't actually take that long (more like 8 hours), but on my MacBook, the backup speeds nonetheless seemed fairly poor. For perspective, I can *download* 450GB over my 1 megabit fiber optic internet connection in around an hour. It's very possible the backup speed is limited by something in MacOS or something in the MacBook hardware, so I can't blame this drive with any certainty.  Plus I care more about reliability, which is an unknown to me until I've used it for around a year.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: It DOES work with mac..
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2022
text: I purchased the 2TB drive, and so far I have mixed impressions on the it. The packaging really threw me off and just felt odd for Seagate.. almost as if it was fake.. but so far it seems legit. But for those saying “it’s not working for my Mac, or did not format right for Mac” they clearly didn’t do their research. The drive comes READY for windows because it’s the most used computer OS.. and regardless It’s ALWAYS recommended to format your new drive regardless of the OS. The drive should be formatted to MacOS Extended ( Journaled) and GUID partition because it works best with spinning disk hard drives. Nothing lasts forever, so make sure you back up your most important data, always. I’ll definitely update this review in the coming months.

title: Backing up The Cloud…
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2022
text: I do use The Cloud to back up my files, but, like many, I have concerns it could just go “puff” one day, for all those assorted reasons, like “Stuff Happens,” as a former Secretary of Defense once proclaimed. So, I also like the idea of all my files on a device that I control, 100%, and fits in my shirt pocket.2 TB is sufficient storage to retain all the photographs I’ve taken over the last half century, as well as all the written words. Both are literally priceless, at least to me.I notice that some reviewers have groused about transfer speeds, but for most of us that is not the highest priority. Moving pictures to the hard drive is a one-time affair, and who amongst us is old enough to remember when one left the computer run all night long?After a month’s usage, the files have been successfully retained, with no copy errors.I’m impressed that this one item has 186,000 plus reviews, the most I have seen for any product. The vast majority are 5-star rating – to be precise, 84%.The only thing left is the price: $60 is a good price to pay for the additional peace of mind. 5-stars.

title: Simple to use hard drive AFTER the initial setup
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2022
text: This product gets the job done AFTER the initial setup and clicking through the user interface from Seagate. If you are a Mac user, I would recommend finding a different external hard drive to purchase for a simple plug and play purchase. To make this usable on your Mac, you need to follow a fairly detailed sequence of steps through system preferences on your Mac. This is definitely a "tech native" purchase for those under 40 years old and that have some familiarity with how to reformat external drives to be compatible with a Mac. For PC users, this is a simple plug and play for the most part, and you can drag/drop content very soon after installing. An additional hurdle for Mac users is that the default shipment is USB. So, you need to have a USB-C to USB converter handy in order to use it. Yet again, another hurdle that would stop some non-native tech folks.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Works as described
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2020
text: Backing up multiple old storage devices since 2004 needed new hard drives.If you don't know, hard drives don't last forever.Drop and drag the file. Takes roughly over night and to a day. Done.I do use iCloud for my mac products, movie making, etc.But, SLR photography and a bunch of stuff from my last HP prefer keeping hard drives. Plus, no need to leave any of this unnecessarily on the MacBook Pro 2021.Using this for business production and publishing so wanna keep it underwhelmed by ‘stuff’ and focus on exactly what I need.I like Seagate’s user-friendly storage. With an Aukey, I’m able to plug the old drives easily into the new mac C port.I use to use Carbonite for hard drive storage at a facility. Should something happen to the devices?With this, you have annual renewals for more than the price of a couple of devices and recovery fees. This is a great option if you live in a flood zone or are not comfortable using a device like this.It’s my opinion these have gotten simpler and easier to manage, so it's a preferential thing for me at this point.I'm buying another because I've filled up a one and two TB backup. Want one for just the HP. Mostly RAW photos from pro photography shoots.I recommend this device if you need a simple to use hard drive for all your data, photos to valued work.Makes it very easy to use between devices without them loading down their hard drives.⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️💯

text: I made a critical error some time ago: I purchased the entire Assassins Creed franchise in digital format.  Buying them wasn’t the error mind you…they’re each and every one a classic and quite a load of fun.  But, I digress…The error arose when Halo Infinite came out.  Suddenly, I had no memory on my Xbox.Now, I had completed the entire Ezio collection, AC III, and Black Flag at this point…but I was still working my way though Unity (greatly underrated game) and still had Syndicate and Rogue.  Plus, I still had side quests in Origins, Odyssey, and a few in Black Flag left.  Needless to say, deleting just wasn’t an option I was entertaining.Enter our titular hero: the Seagate External Hard Drive.  I ordered it, plugged it in, quick and easy setup, and the next thing I knew I was happily plowing through Grunts in a Warthog.Job well done Seagate, job well done.

title: Excellent product and customer service
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2022
text: Seagate was so helpful correcting a faulty drive issue and terrific from start to finish. I purchased an external drive, and the drive did not show up in file explorer. It crashed which happens with hardware. I keep files in the cloud, so it wasn't an issue.I did want the drive replaced, so I called customer service and they were wonderful! The rep was knowledgeable, told me I had a warranty (I didn't know I had one), could return the drive for a new one, and even sent me a prepaid mailing label! He told me they would try to retrieve my data and he couldn't guarantee a successful recovery. The drive was back within 2-1/2 weeks with all my files recovered!I also didn't know the drive they sent me was a temporary backup and was surprised when I received a brand-new drive in the mail. It's working perfectly. The file transfer speed is excellent for an HD. It measures 3"x5"x1" so you can throw it into a pocket or purse. All-in-all, a 10*+ rating.I was not reimbursed for this review :) Definitely recommend.

title: How to use for Mac
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 12, 2022
text: The basic format of this HDD was " Windows NT file system" which can use only for Windows. Changed the format to ExFAT which allows using Mac and Windows. Now I can use both Mac and Windows!At Mac: Open Finder→Go(Top let bar)→Utilities→Disk Utility→Choose HDD→Erase→change the Format to ExFAT→click Delete→complete.Hope this helps other people.

title: Perfect for PS4
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 30, 2020
text: I purchased the 2 TB portable drive for my PS4 (which has only 320 GB). It greatly increased the storage of my game console although I had to use one of the only two available UBS ports. So far I have no complaints about it; the unit was easy to install; the PS4 recognized it immediately, but I had to change the settings so the PS4 used the portable as the primary storage unit and only after the PS4 reformatted the unit. Afterward I had to uninstall some of the games and reinstall them again so the PS4 would store the data in the new drive but with that out of the way, I was able to then reinstall many of the games I had to remove previously because of the lack of storage space. It's a good buy, I do recommend it. Please remember that this is is not an SSD but a hard drive.Pros: Plenty of storage, easy to install, very quiet (not totally, of course).Cons: Not as fast as an SSD.On a side note: I recommend you consider adding a battery backup (UPS) for your PS4 to protect the drives from damaged in case of brownouts or sudden blackouts. I bought a small battery backup unit for 40 US from Amazon, since 2 TB is just too much data to lose.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: My Bad - Use Guid Partition Map
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 1, 2020
text: I wrote my first review stating that I could not partition this drive.  When trying to partition a second drive, I discovered my mistake.  By default, my computer choose the scheme Master Boot Record when formatting, disabling the ability to partition.  When I formatted a second time and chose Guid Partition Map, I was able to partition.  Seagate, your technician should have mentioned this when we troubleshot the problem.Initial ReviewI partition 2TB hard drives into two sections: one for Time Machine and one for manual backups (multimedia).  Every three years I retire the hard drive and start a new one so I have backups for over a decade and I have reliable hard drives. All of my non-multimedia data is backed up to iCloud and Dropbox.I'm confident that the vast majority of these drives work perfectly but I couldn't partition mine.  I tried two methods, two formats, two different OS computers and one Windows computer.  I swapped out the cable and how it connected to the computer.  There was no signs of damage to the box or to the hard drive.  I reinstalled NTFS for Mac, per Seagate's recommendations.  I chatted for 15 minutes with Seagate before we both decided to return the hard drive.  I'll go back to Silicon Power for the replacement.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Very touchy and easily disconnected
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 18, 2022
text: The connector to the drive's body is wiggly and the drive gets disconnected too easily. Even a slight movement of the cord causes it to get disconnected. This has already resulted in a partition that cannot be mounted [wasted space]. In fact, I'm fortunate I partitioned the 2 TB drive into 2 1 TB partitions before I started using it. I can only get one partition mounted. For the one that is corrupted, I had to go in and create another volume, which ends up isolating the used portion of the bad partition so that I can at least use that space.However, the easy disconnection is a real pain and risks damaging the drive. Very sad, since you never know if it will disconnect.Also, as others have mentioned, it's very slow. The cable might be the problem. Next time, getting a flash drive to time machine my mac.My advice: as soon as you can, partition the drive so if one section turns useless, you can still use the other partition. The useless volume sometimes appears and most times does not appear when I connect it to my Mac. Use DiskUtil to set up at least two partitions (not volumes). Use one for time machine and format the other exFAT so you can use it both on Mac and Windows. The exFAT partition seems more resilient than the APFS side. Once the APFS side goes bad, add additional Volumes that can use the space that is still good.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: How to improve this drive's Windows "Create System Image" backup performance
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 22, 2022
text: I replaced another external hard drive I use to do Windows System Image backups. When I first plugged it in and did the backup it took 3 hours to perform a 140 Gbyte backup. Uncomfortably long time. I was able to reduce the time from 3 hours to 40 minutes by enabling write caching in Windows. This is outlined on Seagate's website, but here is a brief description:  Device Manager-> Expand Disk Drives->Right-click the external drive ->Policies Tab->Select Better performance-Select Enable write caching on the device (only)I also disabled indexing on the external harddrive by using File Explorer->right click external drive->properties->deselect indexing.

text: So it was high time I bite the bullet and get one of these and stop relying on a million flash drives and the cloud to back up all my files. I like having redundancies, so I won't be clearing out the flash drives any time soon, but this puts my mind at ease that my documents are safe in yet another place. The drive works as it should and I've had no issues storing or transferring files from one machine to another. There was one hiccup: The drive must be formatted before you can use it and the pre loaded files that should walk you through that process were not compatible with my device. I was, however setting it up on a Macbook Pro running Sierra, so that's more on me than the manufacturer. If you are using a more recent OS, I would assume you would be less likely to encounter this same issue. It wasn't too much of an inconvenience, because you can format the drive yourself using Disk Utility. I just had to google which format I wanted it configured in and it took just a few min. The storage should be more than adequate for my needs as I m using MAYBE an eighth of it to store all my files, which includes lots of video and music files.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Very Very Slow Writes, We Tested It
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 19, 2019
text: I got the 8TB drive to backup a Synology NAS over USB.  We tested the speed of the drive and were shocked at how slow its write speeds were.  Read on for our test results and impressions--  THE TEST:  We ran LAN Speed Test which is a Benchmark speed test tool to test the speed of the  USB 3 port of our laptop to the Seagate drive using 4MB test files.--  SLOW WRITES TEST RESULT:  See the attached graph.  We saw about 21 MB/s write and 150 MB/s Read.  The manufacturer claims 150 MB/s but they dont tell you if its read or write.  A bit of marketing specmanship on their part. --  POOR INDICATORS:  There is a small HDD activity indicator on the rear top.  Very hard to see from its location and from its dim brightness.  Its shocking they did not light up their logo on the front as that would have been a much superior solution. --  NO POWER LIGHT:  There is no power light on either the adapter or the drive body.  So the only way to know if its on is to see the activity light when data is being transferred.  --  NO POWER SWITCH:  There is no switch on the drive to power it on or off. --  NO SIDE MOUNT FEET:  the feet are only located on the large area side.  Even though the disk will work fine on its side, they did not provide any feet on that side. THE GOOD:  -- RECOGNIZED IMMEDIATELY  The drive was  recognized immediately by Windows 10 and by Synology DS220J NAS.  --  SYNOLOGY HYPER BACKUP WORKS:  The Hyper Backup software had no problems using the USB drive as a destination.  The drive was just slow performing at about a 29 MB/s average  for a 3.5 TB backup. CONCLUSION:  The Seagate drive is molasses slow  with a very poorly located activity light.  It might take 1.5 days to complete but incremental changes after the first backup should happen within much less time.If you found this review helpful, you can vote "Helpful" using the button below.

I did have to buy a USB-C cable to connect this drive to my iPad, but soon as I connected it could read the drive and transfers files with no issues or added instructions.  2Tb is definitely large enough for my files, pictures and music.  I can now keep my inner peace knowing that my info is backed up and kept safely in my firebox.  I know someone may say that I could keep my backup on the cloud.... but to be quite honest, I have seen to many movies to trust the cloud when the end of the world comes... I’d rather have all my data in my Levi jeans pocket while I’m hiding in a bunker waiting for the radiation to subside... ; )

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: It works, NTFS format, Average Speed for USB-3, Good Value.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2021
text: It worked properly out of the box on a PC.  It comes formatted as NTFS (for Windows).  It also comes with Seagate utilities to reformat it for Mac.  However, since I use mine for both Windows and Mac, I used the format utility built into Windows to reformat it to exFAT.  With that format it works properly on either Windows or Mac.  Performance has been average.  Write transfer speeds vary from about 30 to 110 MB/sec (240 to 880 Mbps) depending on the files being transferred.  This is close (maybe 10% slower) to the best speeds I have seen from a basic USB-3 portable hard drive.  I have had good luck with reliability on Seagate drives in the past, but that remains to be seen on this one after only a few weeks of use. So, all-in-all, it seems to be a good value for the low price.

I also wanted it to automatically back up my most up to date files, when plugged in.  I plugged it in every day, thinking I was backing up my business files. title: Works Great Bought A Second One!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 21, 2020
text: So I ordered my first hard drive to use as external storage for my PS4. It arrived on the day it said it would and I opened it up and checked it out, it had no signs of damage and I promptly plugged it into my PS4. I chose the format as extended storage option and it worked perfectly, I then moved some of my games over and have used it ever since, no hard drive crash or any problems at all so far.I ordered the second one for storing pictures, videos and movies from my computer. Unlike the last one which arrives on time this one arrived a day early so I was suitably impressed. Anyway I’ve been using it for about a month or so now and it’s going great.Please note from the 2TB, only about 1.81TB is available for you, the rest is system software etc for the hard drive itself. product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Be extremely careful with this device
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 9, 2019
text: Overall I like Seagates external hard drives.  Even though this is my 3rd one in 3 years...  The storage capacity, and portability are their biggest pros.  However there could be a lot done to the device to make it better.  First off you have to be very careful when handling this device, one drop, or it hitting something in your bag during transport, can, and more than likely will cause irreparable damage.  I have gone through three because of this.  The first one dropped less than a foot, hit the carpet, and quit working.  The second one hit my laptop while I was driving home, and quit working.  The third one I didn’t drop at all, and it randomly quit after 5 months.  Luckily they’re good about their warranties, even though the application on the website is a humongous pain in the ass.  I had to restart it over 5 different times because it would randomly take me back to the home page, and you couldn’t read or click on half of the parts.  Needless to say after 3 hours of trying, I stopped and contacted them over the phone.  The person who helped me was extremely nice, and apologized about the technical issues on the site.  The second thing they could work on to make it better would be to work on the heat issue, this device gets extremely hot after using it for hours.  Lastly they could make, or purchase a better usb2.0/3.0 cord; the ones they give you are absolute crap.  They last for a few months, 6 at most before they stop working.  My guess is it’s a cheap product purchased in bulk.  If Seagate would take the time to fix these issues, I believe they would have the best EHDs on the market.  Only because of the portability, storage capacity, and customer service do I give this product 3 stars.  Without those three things, I’d advise people not to buy them.  However I do warn people to proceed with caution, and be extremely careful when using one.

title: Good drive
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2021
text: I had a Toshiba 1tb drive that appeared to stop working.  I ordered thiSeagate 2TB as a replacement.  When I plugged it in, the computer recognized it as a USB device with the name Portable.  The device manager could see it as a Seagate drive but no capacities shown.  Eventually, I found that if it was plugged into a USB 3 connector and you populate the volume it would show capacities and all else necessary to work.  My Toshiba 1 TB also recovered by doing the same for it.  The USB connectors on the front of my computer which had been fine for the Toshiba in the past are USB 2.  Apparently, Microsoft in one of it's recent updates must have removed that ability by plan or by bug.  I added a USB 3 expander to add and bring four USB 3 ports out to the front for ready access.So now I have two external drives,both of which work fine.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: 2TB (backup drive).  Ok performance.  Doesn't appear to be fake, but "Frustration-Free Packaging???"
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2021
text: When I received my drive, I was a bit concerned because I received it in "Amazon's Frustration-Free Packaging."  I would not have purchased this drive if I knew it wouldn't come in original packaging!  It wasn't even an option.I took some steps to try to feel better that I hadn't gotten a non-authentic drive.  I checked the labelled S# against the firmware S# (lsusb), and they match.  Verified the case and labels seems to match images on other vendor sites.  Without opening the case, that's about the best I can do to verify it's authenticity.Plugged into USB3, and began a backup of about 650GB data.  Transfer speeds peaked at about 80M/sec, and lowest about 20M/sec.  Took a couple hours to complete transfer.  Good enough for incremental backups going forward.

text: I haven't had any problems with this product, so I couldn't award any STARS in this rating for "support". Like I said, I haven't had any problems with this external drive. It was plug & play, right out of the box, with the cable provided. If I had the ability to make one change to this device, it would be with the cable end that plugs into the drive. I would have used a USB C connector, so it wouldn't matter which way you grabbed the device end of the cable (no flipping) to plug it in. USB C connectors should be universal on ALL external drives, by ALL manufacturers. This is a good product, overall. Very affordable.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: 100 MB/s 2TB Backup Hard to Beat at this price point
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 23, 2021
text: I got this for $60 from amazon and have been using it to edit HD video (1920x1080) from my camcorder and iphone, and been using it as a backup. The read/write speeds are over 100 MB/s. Thats megabytes, not megabits. For a single drive, non raid, that isn't an SSD, just a standard drive plugged in to usb 3.0, this thing is fast. Of course an SSD will be several times faster, but also several times more expensive. If you are editing 4k video, RAW camera footage, skip this and get an SSD. If you are looking for a solid, portable, inexpensive drive for backup, portability, editing HD video, its' hard to go wrong with this one.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Wish I hadn’t thrown out the box.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 28, 2023
text: My last external took a crap after a few years so with all the great reviews I decided to give this one a shot.This drive takes FOREVER to back up data. I tried to transfer all my data at once and so many photos/vids got left out of the transfer along with it taking all day for less than 100 gb’s.Because it takes so long I figured I’d transfer photos/vids by year. When cross checking to make sure all data had been transferred I found that so many didn’t end up onto the drive again.I got no error message about the files that couldn’t be transferred, etc. they just simply don’t show up which is pretty annoying because you don’t know what didn’t transfer.I wish I had saved the box to return this. I told myself when I first got it to not be impatient because it’s slow but with the drive being unreliable with data not transferring over and having to monitor what you’re transferring over its turning out to be more of a hassle.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: So far so good, but watch your privacy
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2020
text: Just received my drive today. It was super easy to set up. Just plugged it in and was good to go. Disappointed it didn't come with backup software.If you click on the Start_Here icon for Windows, it takes you to their web page where you can register your warranty. HOWEVER, watch out! One is asked to agree to their terms and conditions, privacy policy and optional offers. I had to do some digging in the privacy statement, and discovered that basically you are agreeing to be tracked by dozens of companies across the internet. You have to dig further to find the opt out button. I tried it, but after several minutes of waiting, it wouldn't let me proceed. I am guessing that's because I already have a bunch of privacy protections on my internet browser, and they wanted my cookies turned on. No, thanks.  I decided not to even register for the warranty. This level of invasion of privacy is UNACCEPTABLE when I have paid to purchase this product.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Loads of storage capacity!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
text: I started running out of storage space on my pc, and a friend of mine suggested an external hard drive.  So, I bought this one, and I am amazed at the storage capacity.  I won't have any more problems with storage now.  The one problem I have is that it's not as portable as I'd like it to be.  It's a little bit smaller than some of the smart phones out there, so if you're  traveling it would be best to keep it in a suitcase or some other secure storage container.  I do like that it comes with a USB cable that you can use to plug it right into your desktop.  And one more thing: When transferring files from your desktop to the external hard drive, it can take anywhere from 15-45 minutes to move the files, depending on how many files you move at one time.

text: I bought this external hard drive to clean up my two computers. I went through all the technical recommendations other than uploading all the files to a website and nothing worked. The second issue I had was when I ejected the device from one computer and opened it on another computer it wouldn't show me the documents I saved from the other computer. Again I tried all the technical solutions and nothing. I ended up recovering everything from both computer recycle bins and now Im back to square one with a paperweight hard drive and three hours of wasted time. I would send it back but now I'm worried about them recovering data even though I wiped it.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Buyer Beware
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 21, 2022
text: I bought a few variations of this product as there are two PS5s in my home that needed the extended storage. One, purchased in February still works. The other, purchased about a year ago...well... keep reading. I saw a few reviews that warned of the hard drive suddenly malfunctioning and losing all of the stored data. I thought it was probably just a few malfunctioning units and took the chance on this hard drive anyway. The price was attractive and it seemed easy to use. For $99 I guess you get what you pay for. I will say, this product worked PERFECTLY in the beginning and was just what I needed. However, none of that really matters when one day you boot up your Playstation and literally EVERYTHING is wiped. The worst part is, I can't even seem to repair the it in any way after hours of googling and trial and error. Worth noting, I am very tech savvy so if there was a way to fix it...I would've found it.  Now, I've just got a very expensive paperweight and have to download my entire game library again. Here's hoping I have my save files in the cloud. This is a gamer's worst nightmare. So in short, feel free to roll the dice on this harddrive... it may work perfectly for you. However, to me, the fact that it malfunctioned so early in it's life cycle and many others have had the same problem, this is simply unacceptable. If I had known, I probably wouldn't have purchased the second unit.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)

title: How to format for PS4
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 25, 2021
text: I bought this for for my son's ps4. When we first plugged it in the ps4 said it didn't recognize this device or something. The trick to formatting was once I went to device settings, usb devices, find the device....hit options, and format to exFat. The go back to usb devices and hit stop using it, unplug and plug it back in. Then it allowed me to set it up as external. Hope this helps, game on!

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Great way to expand storage on your PS4 console.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2021
text: Today's console games are so large, that even with a 1TB internal drive on the console, you can quickly run out of disk space after a few large games have been installed (RDR2, Final Fantasy VII, Horizon Dawn, etc.).  Hooking up one of these bad boys to the USB 3.0 port on the back of the PS4 works like a champ.Drive was detected and doesn't take too long to format.  Migrating games from the internal storage to the new drive is straight forward but will take some time (depending on how big the game is).  Games on the external drive actually load faster than from the internal drive.For the price, it's a no-brainer if you need to increase your console storage by 2TB.

title: Save your money.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 28, 2021
text: It was affordable for a reason. Lasted me awhile for sure but awhile isn't good enough if it's an integral part of your system. And it didn't just quit on me. It made a whole 6 month long event about it where I'd have to find ways of appealing its whims because my charge cable for my controller had the nerve to slightly brush the cord the drive came with. Then there's the wonderful times where it would be connected and just decide that nah its not and I'm seeing things. I need to just unplug it and restart the console and hope it decides to work and need repair because it wasn't disconnected properly. Which every time I had to do that I was gambling since it could very well corrupt every file on there. I did that a lot. I'm not sure what I did to upset it enough to finally give up entirely but I'll be honest, we're both in a better place for it. I leave with more patience and gray hairs, but at least it's done.Don't buy this jank garbage. Just get a more reliable one that costs more. In the end, it really doesn't.

title: Worked for my PS4!! Saved me $$
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
text: I wasn't sure this would work for my PS4, so I went to Gamestop prior to purchasing and asked the gamer guys if it would work.  They said that this would be perfect as long as it is hdd 3.0, just needs to be formatted to the PS4. Glad to hear it because this saved me like $30 (the ps4 seagate is $90+).  Plugged it in before turning on my ps4, went to settings>devices, selected the external storage, ps4 prompts you if you would like to format, after a series of yes's and OK's, the hdd was formatted.  You have to then go to your storage and select the games you want to move to the external memory.  Took about an hour to transfer my 8 games from the internal memory to the external seagate, but now I have room for about 50 more games!! Save yourself a few bucks and get this one for your ps4!

text: My 900GB Windows 10 PC was down to 250 GB left and was loaded with pictures, videos, and music. The backup unit was full and stopped a year ago adding files. File copies were saved on 26 USB Flash drives from A-Z and something had to be done for speed and efficiency. A 2TB Seagate for $56.99 from Amazon was the answer to my dilemma. It is fast, moving files to it and opens them quickly. I have only moved picture files and some video so far and increased my PC's free capacity to over 50%. There is no app that you have to use to get into the files stored there and works just like a flash drive with all the folders that were moved from your PC.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on June 6, 2021
text: As a long-time Seagate user, I was nearly tempted away from this drive by some of the more negative reviews.  Upon arrival, I did encounter some of the confusing setup quirks others have dealt with.  However, all doubt was eliminated with a bit of extra reading upon registration.  Windows users have no fear.  Just plug in properly and go for a free download of Seagate's Toolkit software.  Once installed, you'll be able to automate backups or drag and drop files as you like.  And yes, basic File History back up should work also with storage space to spare since Toolkit installs on your computer and not the drive itself.  I actually wish this had been available years ago!

title: This one has a problem with existing USB cables
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2021
text: I can had no problems using my existing usb cables with this hard drive on my PC.  However, this hard drive was not recognized by my Patroit Box and Samsung TV using the cables that I have been using with other hard drives.  It finally worked with the new cable that came with the drive.  This drive probably needs a little more juice or something for it not to work with cables that work with about 10 other hard drives that are 2TB or larger.  Disappointed that this one is so unique that I would have to change cables which means it is not the same plug and play that I am used to with my portable hard drives.  This is not my first Seagate so it is disappointing that it is not as interchangeable as the others.  It is not worth the trouble of returning for another one which may have the same issue.  I wonder if this one is a one-off defect or a sign of what to expect from future purchase of this brand.  I am not going to bother experimenting this with my Roku Ultra or other streaming devices.  It's not worth the extra work to try it with every streaming device that I own.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Just installed in Tivo Bolt Works Great (by disassembling the Tivo Bolt of course)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2019
text: Just installed 2TB version to replace 500GB drive in my Tivo Bolt.  Keep in mind for those that don't know(to the best of my knowledge) Tivo only supports old models of esata hard drives of specific models).  This is a USB3 model that I disassembled and removed the drive to install in my Tivo Bolt.  I am not running Hydra but otherwise running latest software as of 2/2019.  Installed the new drive and booted Tivo without issue.  The Tivo Bolt will boot with this as a blank drive and install the OS on it's own.  Just as an FYI after prying the external enclosure apart the internal drive model is ST2000LM007.I still find it odd that drives in enclosures are less expensive that the bare drive.  But anyway this was much less expensive that purchasing a more expensive Tivo with a larger drive.  Tivo is still the best DVR.  Sad that I think we will see it go away as streaming is taking over.  I currently have satellite TV but am going to use this for OTA for local channels and streaming for the rest then drop satellite.  Hope someone finds this useful.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Don't trust the Company
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2022
text: After downloading all my information on Hard Drive my computer said the drive wasn't properly ejected and it was still attached.  My computer wouldn't recognize the drive again, so I called the company and went through all the trouble shooting with them. Nothing worked and drive started making a humming noise and the support person said that's not good we'll have to replace it. I was fine with that as long as they sent me the replacement and a return label. I asked several times if this was the case and was told yes.  I never received an email saying the new drive had shipped to me. Just an email about feedback from the call I made.  I contacted them through chat on the sea gate web site. He asked if I had received an email regarding a credit card authorization. I asked why would you need that. He didn't answer me. I told him I was supposed to get a replacement drive then I was supposed to send the broke one back. I was very uncomfortable about sending the broken drive back anyways because I had backed up all my info on to that drive and they boast recovering information off hard drives that are damaged. They said they'd send me a free return label but had to send broken drive back first. I have a problem with companies that change what they say in the first place so I'm just returning the drive to Amazon and getting a refund. I don't feel comfortable though because they still have the drive and everything from my computer is on that broken drive. Maybe they can or can't fix the drive, but I feel there so much fraud out there how do I know what happens with my information that can or can't be recovered on the drive I'm sending to God know who.

text: I wouldn’t say I used this drive much. Was just a backup but it stopped working anyways.  So if you’re looking for dependable storage, look elsewhere. I will say all the small portable drives Ive used in the past few years by other manufacturers have pretty much all failed to work after a few months. I have drives made 10 years ago that still work fine. Not sure what’s going on with the manufacturing of hard drives these days, but they just don’t work. And it’s terrible to have your photos or high quality  music files being stored on untrustworthy devices. That’s what we are left with as consumers.

title: Price to ratio is great. May not be new, suspect packing.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2021
text: So after reading the mixed reviews I bit the bullet and got this. It arrived on time and everything seemed okay till I opened the amazon shipping pouch. The hard drive arrived in a brown "hassle free" box and the box itself looked like it had been opened before, as the label with the info was torn and so was the box flap. I hooked it up to my Xbox and it formatted and transfered the games with no issue. So far it's working as intended, but the reviews seems to be hit or miss on it lasting more than a few months for some unlucky people. Time will tell. For what it's worth, it's inexpensive and a good effective little drive for the price to TB ratio. The only concern I have is the fact that it's meant to be a new unit, and it was shipped and sold by Amazon.... but this could be a repacked or refurbished unit and there's no way to confirm this. Just gotta wait and see what happens.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Customer Service
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2022
text: If you have an issue with the product, dealing with Customer Support is very time consuming.  Our unit quit working.  It was still under warranty.  I spent close to 2 hours working with Customer Support to get a replacement.  You have to pay shipping on the device to return. They also wanted me to return the device fully intact.  It was not responding so I could not delete data on drive.  I had to fight to be able to destroy the data storage so their company did not have access to what I had stored on the device.  I had to get "special permission" to destroy the drive before I returned it.  I would not purchase any product from this company.  Even though the support representative assured me that the data on my device would be 100% secure and protected their own Warranty statements indicates that your product may be sent to countries where protection of data may not be the same.  Directly from their warranty statement "By returning your product to Seagate, you agree to the Seagate repair process as described in the Seagate Return Policy, including the transfer of your data to countries that may not offer the same level of data protection as your home country, as well as the deletion of your data."

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Cheaply made
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2022
text: I got this for my laptop as I needed a lot of storage for rendering projects, after 3 months of use its flaws really show. Recently it has started to have major connection issues. The connection port on the drive became loose due to the heat it produces (It shouldn't be hot enough to melt frozen wax in a few moments...) and will fall loose and disconnect without looking loose or disconnected. I cannot count the amount of time this has cost me on my projects as it disconnects immediately closing whatever program is accessing the files on the drives (i.e. crashing my programs...) and sometimes corrupting the files altogether. I have tried to contact Seagates customer support but I cant even get past the first step as the they require a serial number that is not even on the product. In short, if you are looking to buy this, don't unless your fine with a 3 month usage period ( Just enough time that the return policy is out the window).

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Can Potentially Cause Conflicts - Xbox One
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 27, 2021
text: I bought this for my husband's Xbox One.I've trusted Seagate drives for years. This one however did not work out so well.I formatted it for the Xbox, I started downloading some games & randomly it would just stop & would no longer be recognised. The bigger issue is that it also prevented the Xbox internal drive from being recognised. I ended up doing several restarts of his Xbox as well as a couple of power cycles but it never fixed it.Just to be sure it wasn't his Xbox at fault, I tried it on mine. I re-formatted it & started to download a couple of different games & unfortunately I encountered the same issue on mine. I know my Xbox is fine since I have my own external drive that I've never had an issue with (mine is Western Digital,) so through elimination, it turned out to be this Seagate drive at fault.I may have received a faulty product, that's probably the case, but sadly I can't get a replacement through Amazon so I am unable to say with 100% certainty whether the product is fully compatible with Xbone, I can only get a refund. Not happy about this.For the record, I think Amazon refused to do a replacement because I bought this for $59.99 & after purchasing, it went up to $62. Personally, as a gesture of good-will, replacing it & foregoing that $3 would've been a better and more efficient way to appease a Customer & resolve an issue. For the first time, I am pretty disappointed with Amazon Customer Service. I would've been more than happy to have paid that extra $3 but I wasn't even offered that option. Amazon just lost Seagate a Customer because I am reluctant to buy another now incase I encounter the same issue & have to go through the same return process & wait again before I can buy something else. I'll get another WD instead. Sorry Seagate :(

Windows backs up regularly, but I manually back up Outlook email and my files stored on my other external hard drive which are not kept on my PC. Seagate has never disappointed me.

title: Not for Apple Mac
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 25, 2022
text: First I want to say I have two other Seagate external hard drives in the past and been satisfied. I purchased this with the intent of using it on my new MacBook Pro. When I plugged in the drive, the Seagate Portable Drive icon appeared on my desktop. I opened it and got three choices, "start here for mac," a windows option and a warrenty info file.I clicked on start here for Mac and a window popped up saying it could not open due to the drive be (something like faulty) or "incomplete." I called Seagate and although there were some language issues I patiently tried to stay on the line as the CSA said I had to format the disk. Long story short, disk utilities, click erase, CSA said what happened next was not right and started reading something about how "although the drive is for Mac, it may yada, yada yada. I thanked her and have returned the item. I've never had a problem with Seagate before, but between the product not functioning and bad CSA service, I did return it.

I set this as my preferred installation location and have all my games on it.Recently I got a second Xbox one. The coolest thing is that I can simply plug this into whichever box I'm using (one in the living room and one in the bedroom) and all my games are there. No installing on each Xbox or whatever. Just swap over the drive and I'm golden.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Works with PS4
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 8, 2019
text: I'm using this specifically for my PS4 and it's as simple as plug into console, format, and copy/move games over. It's really that easy. Took about an hour and fifteen minutes to move Modern Warfare, Apex Legends, and Borderlands 3 over from console to HDD. I have the original Destiny edition PS4 and it only comes with 500GB so this was much needed. I have had to delete so many games over the years to maintain storage but now I won't have to worry about that issue. I regret that I waited so long to get this. A USB hub will not be able to sufficiently power this, it must be plugged directly into the console USB port. I feel like navigating the PS4 dashboard is much more fluid and smoother and the game load times have improved a little bit.

title: Some Issues..
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2020
text: I bought this 2TB external because of the price and portability. I didn't want the software that came with it so I reformatted it to FAT32. I have several external drives and never had this problem when formatting to FAT32. I primarily use an Apple iMac for work and everyday usage. Every time I booted up my Mac the external drive would say error and could not mount disk. I was ready to pack it up and return it but decided to reformat it again as a Mac OS Extended (Journaled) and ran it through Disk Warrior and it seems to be working now with no problems. Not sure if I can still trust this baby. The minute it hiccups or looks at me sideways, I'm sending it back..UPDATE: Worked fine for a few months then This POS lost all my back up work files.. I'm not a newbee to computers and drives. I've taken my MAC apart several times to do hardware upgrades.. Thank goodness I backed up my files in another external drive... This external drive is not dependable..

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Didn't last long
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2023
text: Worked for a couple weeks, then stopped being recognized.  Windows11 says it's "working properly" in Device Manager, but I can't see the drive.  It also makes a constant buzzing/beeping noise as if it's trying to activate.I've hooked it up to my USB-C port and hooked it up to all the USB ports on my laptop and it still doesn't recognize and still makes the buzzing/beeping noise.  Hooked it up to my other countless PC's running in the house and same results.Only conclusion is that the drive is bad and it's too late to send for refund/replacement.Good thing I never put any data on it.I'll be looking at more reliable models to purchase.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Comes with 181Mb less than advertised!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2021
text: I ordered 2TB, and got 181mb less. So in order to get closer to the full 2TB that the description says, one must delete the manufacturer software folder etc.Other than that it works right out of the box for Windows 10 OS. It's plug an play.Testing the transfer read/write speed to see what the OS tells me for different size folders and files. The transfer rate varied from 862kb to 65 MB/s - see attached. As others have said, the transfer speed is slow! 10GB took about an hour to transfer.

title: Not truly Mac compatible because cannot be partitioned
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2020
text: I bought 2 of these drives.  I have bought at least four others for myself and my children's' MacBook Pros.  The drives come formatted for PC which is not a problem.  I was able to reformat for a Mac.  The problem was I could not partition the drive.I want to use some of the space for TimeMachine and the rest for general use.  DiskUtility would not let me. That option never became active no matter how I had it formatted. I tried on a brand new MacBook Pro and a 6-year-old MacBook Pro, which I used for other Seagate drives. Since I bought 2 of them, I tried with the second one and the same result.I returned both of them and bought 2 Seagate Backup Plus Slim drives.  I hope these two will do what I want.  I have bought a similar one for my wife's iMac and partitioned that.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: IF YOU CARE ABOUT YOUR DATA GET A SOLID STATE AND NOT THIS
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2022
text: Huge mistake with this hard drive. Lost everything I've done over the past year. Sent drive into Seagate and customer service is well intentioned but feels about as solid as this hard drive. Anyways cutting to the point, sent it into Seagate for data recovery, and it was unsuccessful. I don't know what to tell you, maybe I'm part of that 2% that doesn't have a good experience with data recovery. Maybe Seagate is great. But I'm traumatized. So back to my title statement, regardless of the company, IF YOU CARE ABOUT YOUR DATA GET A SOLID STATE AND NOT THIS.UPDATE - From Data Recovery that's costing $1000 in response to Seagate's team who worked on data recovery for my external drive > "Im not sure who worked on this drive, but WOW! I haven't seen such carelessness like this in a while. It's really unbelievable.IF Seagate is the only person that worked on this drive, I am honestly speechless. This case may have had a chance at being recovered, but now it's tough to say."If I can sue Seagate, I will.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Did not work for backups
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
text: I bought this for backups on a desktop.  It did not work for me.  It kept on being removed from the system.  I researched the issue, and found two fixes.  Fix 1 was to make changes to the system power settings so USB devices were not powered down.  Fix 2 was to set the disk drive power off timer to never.  Neither of these changes worked.  At some point, the drive disappears from the PC and the drive would need to be disconnected and then reconnected to show up again.  I contacted Seagate for any other fixes.  After 10 minutes on hold a support person noted my issue, then put me on hold to research.  I got hung up on.  Finally just gave up and returned the drive.  This may work for you if you plan on plugging in the drive each time you use it.

title: Dish TV  Wally external hard drive
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2018
text: Ok RV'S  looking for and external hard drive for their  Dish TV Wally (THIS IS IT)!!  This external hard drive does work on your Dish Wally.  I purchased this drive just for this purpose.  Easy to install, once install took Dish 1 minute to activate.One note on installation, there are 2 USB port on the back of your Wally. One USB 2.0 and one USB 3.0. You must connect to the correct USB port. You must connect to the USB 3.0 port. Unfortunately they are not labeled.  The Wally will read the drive on both port and will activate the external drive on both port. But will only record on the USB 3.0 port.  So if it doesn't record after activating change to the other USB port on the Wally.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Works with PS4 after deleting partition
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 6, 2019
text: Was successful in getting this to work with PS4 with a few extra steps. Initially when I plugged in the to the USB port and attempted to format as extended storage it did not work — have a ps error code . Tried rebooting and still no luck.  Ultimately, I needed to plug the drive into my laptop, delete the partition, reformat as fat32 and then try again with ps4.  Ps4 then recognized the drive and allowed me to format as extended storage. Now works great.  Deducted one star for the extra effort that is likely not very intuitive for most.  Ultimately happy with the purchase. Good price and performance.

product_name: Seagate Portable 2TB External Hard Drive HDD — USB 3.0 for PC, Mac, PlayStation, & Xbox -1-Year Rescue Service (STGX2000400)
title: Where to begin... total crap
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 1, 2020
text: Where to begin... I thought I was getting a pretty decent deal on a 2TB hard drive. For a while it seemed to work fine as a xbox one expansion. Eventually we started having issues getting the xbox to allow us to connect controllers to it. I did not even consider that this hard drive was to blame. We would have to restart the xbox a few times to get the connect button to function on the console.Finally we noticed that some of our content wasn't displaying on the console. I looked through the storage and noticed the external hard drive wasn't connecting anymore. Unplugged it, restarted console repeatedly. We tried everything. Finally we got it to connect and low and behold, the controller connect button no longer functions! I still assumed i was dealing with two separate issues.So about now I'm getting pretty frustrated with the whole situation. My external hard drive is trash, and my kid's less than year old xbox one x is apparently on the verge of becoming trash. I unplug the hard drive and move it to a different xbox to see if the storage or the xbox is to blame. Now imagine my surprise when the controller connect button on the second xbox now doesn't work. The hard drive doesn't work either. Everything works fine until I plug in this particular hard drive. And everything goes back to fine when I remove it.Do yourselves a favor and buy a better hard drive.Update - I have started the quest to see if it's possible to return this device back to whatever it came from. So far seagate has said it will not be a problem as long as I give them pretty much every piece of personal information that makes me who I am. They also want me to review their information privacy policy which makes me think that my information will very soon be for sale. I guess I'll just eat the cost of this one.

It's  brand new computer, I plug this external drive into my PC and it's giving me the run around. I use to be able to just plug it in and go, it doesn't show up on my windows explorer. I had to google the info, run a bunch of command prompts and do all this hoopla just to get it to show up on my windows explorer. I'm seriously irritated and even had to format this thing just to get it to work.To make matters worse, why does my computer say the storage space is 1.81 when it's advertised as 2? What a ripoff. title: Read Write speeds are okay for what it is. Updated
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2019
text: Considering that it's a standard 2.5-inch mechanical hard drive the Read Write speeds are okay when using a USB 3.0 port. Lots of room, inexpensive. If you are trying to save edited video, you might want to fork out the extra cash for one that's an SSD. One odd thing and this most likely has nothing to do with this drive, but it won't work when plugged into my front USB 3.0 port on my desktop computer, but my front USB port works just fine with all other USB 3.0  devices. The drive works just fine in my rear USB 3.0 ports and it works in the front USB 3.0 port of another desktop that I have that has the same MB and CPU. My front USB 3.0 is in a Zalman T1 case.My 2TB Seagate drive died on April 11, 2019. So it worked fine for about 2 1/2 months, then died. It just totally went dead and quit working with no warning. Fortunately, I have backups for the data I had stored on it (actually, it was the backup). I had to pay about $8 postage to return the drive to Seagate and they shipped me another new drive (refurb) that I got today. The replacement drive is working okay at this time.
